awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Marginal instability and deep-cycle turbulence during an extreme El Nino event
awd_abstract_narration:
The El Nino is an inter-annual coupled ocean-atmosphere phenomenon, focused in the equatorial Pacific, that influences weather patterns around the world. While the 2015-16 El Nino was the strongest on record, the best available climate models failed to predict it (as well as falsely predicting an event a year earlier that failed to materialize). This project will address the interactions of wind and large-scale oceanic variability with small-scale turbulence and its effect on sea surface temperature in the eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean. The project will use existing observations of ocean structure and turbulence along with high resolution numerical simulations to understand the deep cycling of turbulent mixing and its relation to El Nino. The results will be used to formulate new methods for capturing the effects of turbulence in ocean and climate models.

This project involves analysis of existing data sets and numerical simulations to study deep cycle turbulence under the Equatorial Pacific Cold Tongue during the El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Data from TAO moorings, deployments of chi-pods, and Large Eddy Simulation (LES) modeling will be used to examine marginal instability and deep-cycle turbulence (DCT) during different phases of ENSO. The results will be used to formulate a new parameterization for turbulent mixing in the upper equatorial ocean. The PIs will also address the interactions and roles of tropical instability waves (TIW) and Kelvin waves on DCT and mixing beneath the cold tongue.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The most important physical effect of ocean turbulence is the transport of heat vertically from the surface down into the ocean interior. Heat that remains near the surface can melt sea ice or can be transferred back into the atmopshere the next time the temperature drops, whereas heat that is mixed into the interior by turbulence may not see the surface again for centuries. In the context of climate change, ocean heat uptake reduces the warming of the atmosphere by about 90%. Over all the world’s oceanic regions, the most rapid heat uptake is found in the equatorial oceans, particularly their eastern reaches, where intense tropical sun and converging currents combine to create ideal conditions. For this reason, our group has long been interested in turbulence in the eastern equatorial Pacific ocean.

While turbulence has been studied mainly in the Pacific, this project has confirmed that it’s workings are similar in the Atlantic. Moreover, our latest estimates suggest that equatorial turbulence plays a major role in regulating the global climate. For example, the slowdown (or “hiatus”) of global warming observed in the early 21st century is now known to have been caused by an unusual sequence of La Nina events. The past few years have seen a shift toward El Nino conditions, leading to the much-noticed increase in heat waves, flooding and wildfires. 

An aspect of ocean turbulence that has been known, though not understood, for several decades is that, of the energy contained in turbulent motions, about 20% is expended in transporting heat while 80% is dissipated by friction. Knowledge of this ratio allows us to estimate heat transport based on dissipation, which is relatively easy to measure. But without knowing why the ratio is 28/80, we cannot tell whether this is reliably true. This project has revealed that the 20/80 ratio is due to the phenomenon we call marginal instability, in which a current flickers chaotically between turbulent and nonturbulent states. Though it has been studied mainly in the equatorial Pacific, we have found that marginal instability occurs throughout the world’s oceans, accounting for the ubiquity of the 20/80 ratio and providing clues as to when it is and is not valid.

Because of their difficulty and expense, measurements of ocean turbulence are sparse. For that reason we have developed a collection of “proxies”, estimation formulae based on quantities like wind speed that are easy to measure directly and have been measured in many locations over many decades. Using these proxies, we are able to estimate heat transport due to turbulence at times and places where no direct measurements exist. For example, we have estimated turbulence levels in the eastern Pacific going back to the 1980s. This allowed us to examine the role of turbulence in ENSO. The proxies will also guide the development of parameterizations for use in large-scale global climate prediction models.
